sentences: Yolanda Yvette Adams (born August 27, 1961) is an American gospel singer and host of her own nationally syndicated morning gospel show.
Billboard listed her as the top-selling gospel artist of the decade from 1999 through 2009, driven by the sales of her No. 1 album Mountain High...Valley Low.
Billboard listed her as the top-selling gospel artist of the decade from 1999 through 2009, driven by the sales of her No. 1 album Mountain High...Valley Low.
President Barack Obama awarded her the Presidential Lifetime Achievement Award in 2016 for her volunteer service.
She was inducted into the Gospel Music Hall of Fame by the Gospel Music Association in 2017.
In 2018, she became the first gospel artist nominated for a Tony Award for her work on SpongeBob SquarePants.
In 2019, she received the Soul Train Music Awards Lady of Soul Award, and received critical acclaim for officially opening Super Bowl LIV with her performance of "America the Beautiful".
She graduated from Sterling High School in Houston in 1979.
The choir released the single "For My Liberty" in 1982 with her as the featured vocalist.
In 1986, Adams was featured on the Edwin Hawkins Music and Arts Seminar Choir released Give Us Peace, with a performance entitled "My Trust Lies in You".
Later, she signed a recording contract with Sound of Gospel which yielded her first album Just As I Am in 1987.
In 1990, she was discovered by producer/keyboardist Ben Tankard, and signed to his independent label Tribute Records and released Through The Storm.
He featured Adams' vocals on his album and concept video single "You Bring Out The Best in Me" on his 1994 release Play Me in Your Key.
Her next release was 1995's More Than a Melody, which featured more production work from Tankard with contributions from O'Landa Draper, and BeBe Winans.
Adams' first significant attention outside the urban contemporary gospel arena came with the release of Mountain High... Valley Low in 1999 on Elektra Records.
The album went 2x Platinum in 2000 and won Adams a Grammy Award.
"Fragile Heart" was dedicated to the memory of Adams' long-time road manager, who died in 1998.
In 2000, Adams released a Christmas album, and in 2001 she released a live album (The Experience).
In 2000, Adams released a Christmas album, and in 2001 she released a live album (The Experience).
Believe, which included the hit "Never Give Up" was released in 2001 and reached gold status according to the RIAA.

In 2001, Adams also released a compilation CD entitled The Divas of Gospel; it included the legendary Grammy Award winner Albertina Walker, who was popularly referred to as the "Queen of Gospel Music" until her death in 2010.

In 2001, Adams also released a compilation CD entitled The Divas of Gospel; it included the legendary Grammy Award winner Albertina Walker, who was popularly referred to as the "Queen of Gospel Music" until her death in 2010.
Adams recorded a song for the 2003 film Honey entitled "I Believe", which played during the last scene in the final dance.
After nearly four years without releasing an album, Adams returned in 2005 with Day By Day.
After ending her long association with Atlantic Records, Atlantic released a greatest hits collection entitled The Best of Me in May 2007.
Adams signed with Columbia Records in 2007.
Columbia released What a Wonderful Time, her second holiday collection, in October 2007.
The syndicated show aired for ten years before ending in 2016.

sentences: Adams' eleventh studio album, Becoming, was released on May 3, 2011, produced by Steve Bracey.
The new single, "Be Still", by Drathoven, debuted on Tuesday, April 19 on The Yolanda Adams Morning Show.
At The BET Awards 2012, Adams' won the award for Best Gospel Artist for the 4th time in her career having won the most since the first BET Awards in 2001.

Twelfth studio album: 2013–
Adams released her first book Points of Power in 2010.
Adams was married to Troy Mason from 1987 until 1990.
Adams was married to Troy Mason from 1987 until 1990.
In 1997, Adams married former NFL player Tim Crawford.
The couple divorced in August 2004 after seven years.
Adams and Crawford have one daughter, Taylor Adams Crawford, born in 2001.
Adams was inducted into Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc. as an honorary member on July 8, 2018.

In 2022, she will be inducted into the Black Music & Entertainment Walk of Fame.
On an April 2013 episode of BET's Lift Every Voice, Adams announced that she was working on her twelfth studio album.
Billboard listed her as one of the Top Gospel Artist of the 2010s and has scored five number one albums on Billboard's Top Gospel Album.
Yolanda Yvette Adams (born August 27, 1961) is an American gospel singer and host of her own nationally syndicated morning gospel show.
Billboard listed her as the top-selling gospel artist of the decade from 1999 through 2009, driven by the sales of her No. 1 album Mountain High...Valley Low.
Later, she signed a recording contract with Sound of Gospel which yielded her first album Just As I Am in 1987.
One year later, Adams followed with Save the World, which included her first signature song "The Battle Is The Lord's".
Live in Washington, released the following year, featured versions of material from her first three albums.
In 2000, Adams released a Christmas album, and in 2001 she released a live album (The Experience).
Day
By Day ===
After nearly four years without releasing an album, Adams returned in 2005 with Day By Day.
After the release of What a Wonderful Time, Adams embarked on the radio career with The Yolanda Adams Morning Show which was aired in over 26 radio markets within two years.
